name: Cybersecurity Fundamentals
description: The intent of the Cybersecurity Fundamentals (CSF) Knowledge Unit is to provide students with a basic understanding of the fundamental concepts and vocabulary within the vast cybersecurity discipline. Students must be able to describe the current cybersecurity threat landscape, including the various motivations, objectives, and threats. This KU reinforces adversarial thinking and the need for cybersecurity. Students must also be able to describe the goals of cybersecurity, how risk management informs the approach to cybersecurity, and the principles and best practices of cybersecurity.
outcomes: Define the fundamental principles of cybersecurity.
Describe the goals of cybersecurity.
Describe potential objectives of cyber attackers and their motivations.
Describe various types of cyber attacks.
Describe various common vulnerability types and evaluate their severity.
Describe common mechanisms used to protect against cyber attacks.
Describe cyber defense tools, methods, and components.
Apply cyber defense methods to prepare a system to repel attacks and provide system security.
Describe appropriate measures to be taken should a system compromise occur.
Discuss current events in cybersecurity.
topics: Cybersecurity principles

Vulnerability Management
Basic Risk Management and Assessment (Risk, Threats, Vulnerabilities, Risk Mitigation, Residual Risk, Risk Acceptance, Risk Transference, Risk Appetite)

Attack methods for different vulnerability types
Security Life-Cycle
Applications of Cryptography and PKI
Data Security (e.g., in transmission, at rest, in processing)
Security Models (e.g., Bell-La Padula, Biba, Clark Wilson, Brewer Nash, Multi-level security)
Access Control Models (e.g., MAC, DAC, RBAC, Lattice)
Confidentiality, Integrity, Availability, Access, Authentication, Authorization, Non-Repudiation, Privacy
Malware
Session Management
Exception Management
Security Mechanisms (e.g., Identification/Authentication, Audit)
Authentication, authorization, and accounting (AAA) and access control
Malicious activity detection/forms of attack
Security Governance, Policies, Controls and Appropriate Countermeasures (include Disaster Recovery, Business Continuity, and Incident Response Policies and concepts)
Key Legal issues associated with cybersecurity and privacy (HIPAA, HITECH, SOX, FERPA, GLBA, COPPA, FISMA, GDPR, court rulings on-going)
Ethics (e.g., ethics associated with cybersecurity profession)
Cybersecurity best practices
Current events in cybersecurity
Cybersecurity awareness

name: Cybersecurity Principles
description: The purpose of the Cybersecurity Principles (CSP) Knowledge Unit is to equip students with basic security design fundamentals that enable them to build systems that can be trusted.
outcomes: Differentiate and discuss the principles of cybersecurity.
Describe why each principle is important to security and how it enables the development of security mechanisms that can implement desired security policies.
Analyze common security failures and identify specific design principles that have been violated.
Given a specific scenario, identify and apply the design principles involved or needed.
Understand the interaction between security and system usability and the importance of minimizing the effects of security mechanisms.
topics: Cybersecurity principles (e.g., least privilege, separation of duties, defense-in-depth, least astonishment, fail-safe defaults, economy of mechanism, complete mediation, open design)
Principles of system and software design
Separation of domains and duties
Adequate Security
Isolation (e.g., Compartmentalize/Segmentation)
Encapsulation (e.g., Data protection in Object Oriented Programming)
Modularity
Organizational and system resilience (e.g., Hardened)
Security by design.
Accountability.
Simplicity of design (e.g., Economy of Mechanism)
Minimization of implementation (e.g., Least Common Mechanism)
Open Design
Complete Mediation
Layering (e.g., Defense in depth)
Least Privilege
Leverage Existing Components
Fail Safe Defaults/Fail Secure
Least Astonishment (e.g., Psychological Acceptability)
Minimize Trust Surface (e.g., Reluctance to trust, Zero Trust)
Usability and Management
Trust relationships
Ethics in Cybersecurity
vocabulary: Open Systems Interconnect (OSI) and Transmission Control Protocol/Internet Protocol (TCP/ IP) Models (Segments, Packets, Frames)

name: IT Systems Components
description: The intent of the IT Systems Components (ISC) Knowledge Unit is to provide students with an understanding of the basic components that make up an IT system and their roles in system operation and security.
outcomes: Differentiate and diagram the various hardware components of modern computing environments and their individual functions.
Characterize the networks that interconnect computing components.
Describe the various IT activities and roles involved in managing computing systems.
Understand system and software architectures.
Understand basic security issues in modern computing environments.
Describe how software is managed within an organization.
Properly apply the vocabulary associated with cybersecurity.
topics: Endpoint protection (e.g., Workstations, laptops, tablets, servers, appliances, mobile devices, peripheral devices (Printers, scanners, external storage), wearable devices)
Storage Devices (e.g., external storage drives, filesystems, shared file servers, databases)
System Architectures (e.g., enterprise, cloud, SaaS/PaaS/IaaS, etc.) and enabling technologies (e.g., containers, virtualization)

Intrusion Detection and Prevention Systems, Incident Response
